titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Melanie Dornier photographs, 2013-2016 RL.11523
titlestmt.author: Sylvia Herbold, Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-11-01 16:27:07 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Melanie Dornier photographs

origination.label: source
origination.corpname: Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture

did.abstract: Collection consists of two documentary photography series taken in India by Melanie Dornier. "Mahila Thana: All Women Police Station" is comprised of 56 color digital photographs, taken in 2016, recording daily life inside the walls of the All Women Police Station of Gurugram, Haryana. The images convey the human impacts of woman-specific crimes and social justice, and the role of the police station and its female officers as a safe haven for distressed and abused women. The 54 color digital prints in "Punch My Face: Women's Boxing in India" document the daily life and experiences of Meena Kumari, a wife, mother, daughter, police officer, and boxer, 2013-2016. All prints measure 11 3/4 x 8 inches. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts and the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture at Duke University.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Melanie Dornier is a French documentary photographer who graduated in 2004 with a Masters of Education and Evaluation at the University of Pierre Mendes in Grenoble, France. In 2011 she was nominated for a Salon de la Photo of Paris Emerging Photographer award and in 2016 she received an Oxygen Award.
Dornier is the winner of the 2017 Bettye Lane Award for Feminist Photography, sponsored by the Archive of Documentary Arts and the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged in two sub-series: Mahila Thana: All Women Police Station and Punch My Face: Women's Boxing in India. Prints are in original order as assigned by photographer.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Images may only be viewed for educational, non-commercial purposes; any other use, including print reproductions or distribution by any means requires the photographer's permission.
There is no use or distribution by any means of these images permitted in India until 2028.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Melanie Dornier photographs were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2017.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Digital prints are on HahnemÃ¼hle Photo Rag Smooth 300 gr, printed with Epson 7890-8 colors using the ink UltraKrom K3.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Melanie Dornier photographs, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and encoded by Paula Jeannet and Sylvia Herbold, November 2017.
Accession(s) described in this finding aid: 2017-0126.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of two documentary photography series by Melanie Dornier taken in India. "Mahila Thana: All Women Police Station" is comprised of 56 color digital prints. The photographs - taken during 2016 - record daily life inside the walls of the All Women Police Station of Gurugram, Haryana. The 54 color digital prints in "Punch My Face: Women's Boxing in India, document the experiences of Meena Kumari, a wife, mother, buffalo owner, police officer, and boxer, between 2013 and 2016.

In an artist's statement Dornier describes that in 2012, "...the safety issues of the Indian women and gender violence were brought to the fore by the news of the gang rape and death of a young student in New Delhi, India. Since then funding and action plans have been implemented all around the country. In Gurugram, the millennium city in the state of Haryana, it was decided to open an All Women Police Station (AWPS) as in each of Haryana's districts and this was completed in August 2015. The project 'Mahila Thana,' which is 'All Women Police Station' in Hindi, documents the daily life inside the walls of the AWPS of Gurugram."

On "Punch My Face," Dornier reflects that, "Meena Kumari was born in December 1982 to a modest rural family. Now she is reaching the end of her boxing career and she hopes to soon become a police inspector. In 2001, Meena was one of the first Indian women to become a boxer and enjoyed visibility on the international scene. Her first major fight was confronting her father who believed boxing was not a respectable activity for a woman. Despite this Meena worked harder and harder and quickly reached the national and international stage in the flyweight category (51KG). Back then, female boxers were trained with young boys due to the shortage of women in the ring...at the end of 2016 and at the end of this photo documentary, we see Meena in the first months of her third pregnancy."
Dornier is the winner of the 2017 Bettye Lane Award for Feminist Photography, sponsored by the Archive of Documentary Arts and the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts and the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture at Duke University.

did.unittitle: Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 110 color inkjet photographic prints in the collection form two series: "Mahila Thana: All Women Police Station," and "Punch My Face: Women's Boxing in India." All prints measure 11 3/4 x 8 inches. A printed inventory and artist's statement is located in the box for each series.

did.unittitle: Mahila Thana: All Women Police Station

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With "Mahila Thana," meaning 'all women police station' in Hindi, Melanie Dornier documents life inside a women's police station in Gurugram, Haryana. The color digital prints were taken during 2016. According to Dornier, "in India, policewomen represent only 6.11% of the total police force, a very low figure compared to 9% worldwide. As a result, female police officers are mainly assigned on woman and child crime. Inside Gurugram's AWPS, 25 policewomen and 14 police officers are dealing everyday only with women's cases of crime, violence and divorce."
The images convey the human impacts of woman-specific crimes and social justice, and the role of the police station and its female officers as a safe haven for distressed and abused women.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A female villager is coming to expose her case of sexual harassment to ACP Dhaarna Yadav.

did.unittitle: Punch My Face: Women's Boxing in India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Shot from 2013-2016, Melanie Dornier's series 'Punch My Face' documents Meena Kumari's daily life in Rewari, Haryana. Kumari is one of the first Indian women to become a professional boxer. Characterized by the photograper as "a wife, mother, buffalo owner, police officer and boxer," Kumari hopes to eventually become a police inspector.

did.unittitle: Meena Kumari's mother, Mundi, Rewari District, Haryana, India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Saraswaki Devi Kumari sitting in the family house living room, proud to show her daughter's medals and trophies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Meena is training every day, early morning and late evening.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Haryana's boxing team is training together. The male boxers often train in the ring while females stay down.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To lose her pregnancy weight, Meena has to wear a sweat jacket so that she is not too heavy for her boxing category of 51 KG for the 62nd All India Police Competition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Just after practice, in her living room, Meena is breastfeeding her 9 months daughter nicknamed KuKee.

did.unittitle: Train station, Delhi East Railway station, New Delhi, India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With the Haryana boxing team; Meena, her husband and their daughter will be travelling by train for more than 30 hours to the 62nd All India Police Competition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: At the 62nd All India Police Competition, Meena Kumari along with other female boxers is queueing for a weight check and a medical examination in order to register for the competition.

did.unittitle: Respect for her father-in-law, Police quarter, Madhuban, Haryana, India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Meena is sitting in her living room, when her father-in-law enters the room. She jumps to hide behind the curtain. Her friend, Poonam, gives her a scarf to cover herself. By tradition, she has to cover herself in front of the elders of her in-laws.
